text.content: This article will explain how to create an environment for Angular 2 testing. It uses

rich_text.plain_text: This article will explain how to create an environment for Angular 2 testing. It uses

text.content: and some useful stuffs. And it focuses on simplicity and ease to use. Let’s understand it step by step.

rich_text.plain_text: and some useful stuffs. And it focuses on simplicity and ease to use. Let’s understand it step by step.

text.content:
> npm init -y
> npm i -S @angular/{core,common,compiler,platform-browser,platform-browser-dynamic} rxjs zone.js core-js
> npm i -D typescript webpack@~2.1.0-beta awesome-typescript-loader angular2-template-loader raw-loader node-static @types/node
> $(npm bin)/tsc --init
> touch webpack.config.js index.html
> mkdir src
> touch src/main.ts src/app.module.ts src/app.component.ts src/app.component.html

rich_text.plain_text:
> npm init -y
> npm i -S @angular/{core,common,compiler,platform-browser,platform-browser-dynamic} rxjs zone.js core-js
> npm i -D typescript webpack@~2.1.0-beta awesome-typescript-loader angular2-template-loader raw-loader node-static @types/node
> $(npm bin)/tsc --init
> touch webpack.config.js index.html
> mkdir src
> touch src/main.ts src/app.module.ts src/app.component.ts src/app.component.html

text.content: Yay, We’ve created an awesome application quickly.

rich_text.plain_text: Yay, We’ve created an awesome application quickly.

text.content: To make testing environment, we have to set up Karma test runner at first. Follow the command below:

rich_text.plain_text: To make testing environment, we have to set up Karma test runner at first. Follow the command below:

text.content:
> npm i -D karma jasmine
> $(npm bin)/karma init

rich_text.plain_text:
> npm i -D karma jasmine
> $(npm bin)/karma init

text.content: Now, our test is only one file. So after now, all tests have to be written in test/main.js or add new file into karma configuration every times… Really?

rich_text.plain_text: Now, our test is only one file. So after now, all tests have to be written in test/main.js or add new file into karma configuration every times… Really?

text.content: No! Don’t worry, guys. We can separate tests as modules and bundle it to the single test file. No updates on karma configuration by per test.

rich_text.plain_text: No! Don’t worry, guys. We can separate tests as modules and bundle it to the single test file. No updates on karma configuration by per test.

text.content: As you can see, the test failed. It’s expected totally. But there is an important thing. Can you notice a weird information in that error logs?
